subject: Law
title: Juvenile Justice Philosophy
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Juvenile Justice Philosophy.

hook.text: A 14-year-old commits a serious crime. Should they be tried as an adult? Brain science says their mind isn't finished.

buildup.text: Juvenile justice treats young offenders differently, emphasizing rehabilitation over punishment.

discovery.text: The Supreme Court banned juvenile death penalties (Roper, 2005) and mandatory life without parole (Miller, 2012).

twist.text: States can still transfer juveniles to adult courts. Once there, they face adult sentences and adult prisons.

climax.text: Neuroscience shows the prefrontal cortex‚Äîresponsible for judgment‚Äîisn't fully developed until the mid-20s.

punchline.text: Kids aren't small adults. The law is learning what science already knows.

options: Trial of juveniles in any court
